stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the layout for Part 2 of the overworld, which connects the first and third major areas. While sick, he focused on establishing the main path, placing the entrances for Bowser 1 and Course 3, and solving a key progression problem: how the player gains access to the next section after freeing the Yoshis. This led to the creation of the 'chained Dory' mechanic.

development_findings.summary: Kaze rejected an initial idea for a Yoshi to repair a bridge for 100 coins because it felt out of character for Yoshis and illogical from a narrative standpoint.
development_findings.quote: Yoshis aren't really known for repairing bridges. And it's also like, okay, you just saved him and now he wants money from you.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has a design philosophy of not excessively preventing sequence breaks or 'cheese'. He prefers to let players experiment and find clever ways to bypass obstacles rather than implementing invisible walls or other restrictive barriers.
development_findings.quote: If you find a way around it, be my guest. I don't want to put fake barriers there... I don't want to be a bus kill.

development_findings.summary: An early concept of making the entire overworld island shaped like a Yoshi was abandoned because it was deemed non-essential and did not add meaningful value to the gameplay or world.
development_findings.quote: The island doesn't need to be shaped like a Yoshi. It was just a random idea anyway. It doesn't really do anything for this island to be shaped like a Yoshi.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has significantly modified the game's engine, specifically overhauling the collision system to the point where invisible walls are no longer a feature, distinguishing it technically from the original SM64.
development_findings.quote: My engine actually doesn't have invisible walls anymore... I reworked how Mario handles collision altogether.

development_findings.summary: The final solution for overworld progression involves a chained-up Dory who is freed by the Yoshis after the first boss is defeated. This makes the Yoshis active agents in the world and provides the player with a mount to reach the next area.
development_findings.quote: We could have a Dory in here that doesn't trust you until the Yoshis are back. She is kind of a Yoshi.

development_findings.summary: Kaze states that a potential future PC port of the game would leverage Wiseguy's more efficient static recompilation method, rather than being built upon the existing, less optimized SM64 PC port.
development_findings.quote: If a PC port happens, then it's going to be via ViceGuy's static recompilation. It would be a lot easier to port the PC port to RTYI than RTYI to the PC port.

context_findings.summary: Kaze discusses the legal ambiguity of the project, stating that if Nintendo issued a takedown, he would be motivated to replace the assets and release it as a commercial, original IP.
context_findings.quote: I'm half hoping Nintendo shuts me down. So I have to exchange all the assets for non-Nintendo assets. So I can actually sell it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes formal game design education is ineffective because the field is too nascent. He advocates for self-study, particularly in psychology, to understand and leverage human biases in design, citing the book 'Thinking Fast and Slow'.
context_findings.quote: I think studying game design is relatively pointless, because game design is such a new art that basically all the research that's been done on it so far amounts to basically nothing. It's like physics before the ancient Greeks... A lot of game design is psychology, so just reading a lot of psychology also makes a lot of sense.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a new sponsorship deal with Squarespace that requires him to produce a large volume of video content, which is influencing his short-term project and content strategy.
context_findings.quote: I recently took a sponsor deal with Squarespace. And they're asking me to make 6 videos in 3 months.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is working while severely ill, which is impacting his energy levels and work speed during the stream.
context_findings.quote: I was so sick today yesterday I vomited like six times before it was 10 a.m.

context_findings.summary: Kaze views fame not as an end goal, but as a practical tool for increasing the audience and player base for his projects.
context_findings.quote: The more fame you have, the more people play your stuff. And that's cool.

biobak.summary: Biobak suggested an idea for a video showcasing all of Mario 64's collision walls, which Kaze enthusiastically adopted as a simple way to fulfill part of his Squarespace sponsorship obligation.
biobak.quote: Oh my god, bye like that's such a good idea. I will just do that. Oh my god, that's the freest video ever. That's gonna save me so much time.

biobak.summary: When asked how to learn Blender, Biobak's advice (as relayed by Kaze) was to read the documentation and try everything, a method Kaze endorsed.

zeina.summary: Zeina provided a suggestion for the overworld progression puzzle, but Kaze rejected it because it did not align with the core design principle that progress must be tied to the narrative act of freeing the Yoshis.
zeina.quote: No, that doesn't work Zeina, it has to be from saving the Yoshis that you can make progress.

zeina.summary: Kaze mentions his personal relationship with Zeina, noting she got him sick but is also taking care of him, illustrating their personal dynamic alongside their professional collaboration.
zeina.quote: I got cooties from Zayna. It's sad, but it's true... Zayna made soup and tea.

key_stories.title: The Dory Progression Puzzle
key_stories.summary: The team needed a way to gate progression to a new part of the overworld. After dismissing an idea about Yoshis repairing a bridge as illogical, Kaze and the team developed a more narratively satisfying solution involving a chained-up Dory who is freed by the Yoshis, becoming a mount for the player.
key_stories.challenge: How can the player access the second major part of the overworld after defeating the first Bowser? The solution needed to be narratively consistent and feel rewarding.
key_stories.process: Kaze first considered and rejected an idea where a Yoshi would repair a bridge for 100 coins, finding it out of character. He then brainstormed what freed Yoshis would do, leading to ideas about them enabling transport. This evolved from a simple ridable Yoshi to a more complex and integrated idea involving Dory, a creature who is initially inaccessible but becomes friendly thanks to the Yoshis' intervention.
key_stories.outcome: The team decided on having a friendly creature, Dory, chained up in a lake. After the player defeats the first boss, the freed Yoshis release Dory, who then allows the player to ride her to the new area. This solution makes the Yoshis feel like active helpers and provides a clear, diegetic progression gate.
key_stories.key_quote: What if there's a Yoshi here that you can ride and then you can do his flutter jump to get over? We could just put a Yoshi there.

key_stories.title: The Sponsorship Content Solution
key_stories.summary: Faced with a demanding sponsorship deal from Squarespace, Kaze devised a strategy to create content efficiently. A key part of this plan came from a suggestion by Biobak to make a video showcasing all of SM64's collision walls, an idea Kaze quickly adopted after getting approval from Pannenkoek2012.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze needed to generate six sponsored videos in three months for Squarespace, a high volume of content that required an efficient production strategy.
key_stories.process: Initially, Kaze planned to make videos about each 'actor rework' as easy content. During the stream, Biobak suggested a video showcasing all SM64 collision walls. Kaze loved the idea, checked with Pannenkoek2012 (who originated the focus on invisible walls) to ensure there were no hard feelings, and received his blessing to proceed.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze now has a plan to create a series of videos on his 'actor reworks' and a special, low-effort video visualizing all of Mario 64's collision walls, inspired by Pannenkoek2012. This strategy allows him to meet his sponsorship obligations without derailing the main project's development.
key_stories.key_quote: Oh my god, that's the freest video ever. That's gonna save me so much time, you know what I will do that.
